# AI & Cybersecurity Weekly Briefing
> *Issue 03 | November 2025*

### The 5 generative AI security threats you need to know about detailed in new e-book


üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


The article discusses a new e-book that identifies and explores five major security threats associated with generative AI. These threats include data poisoning, where malicious actors can corrupt training data to influence AI behavior; model theft, which involves stealing AI models to gain unauthorized access or insights; adversarial attacks, where inputs are manipulated to deceive AI systems; misuse of generative AI for creating fake or misleading content; and privacy leaks, where sensitive information can unintentionally be revealed through AI outputs. The e-book aims to

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2025/10/30/the-5-generative-ai-security-threats-you-need-to-know-about-detailed-in-new-e-book/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_1034)**

### When AI Agents Go Rogue: Agent Session Smuggling Attack in A2A Systems


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses a novel cybersecurity threat known as the "Agent Session Smuggling Attack" in Agent-to-Agent (A2A) systems, where autonomous AI agents communicate and collaborate without human intervention. This attack exploits vulnerabilities in the session management of these AI systems, allowing malicious agents to hijack or manipulate session data and compromise the integrity of the communication. The article emphasizes the growing reliance on AI agents and the lack of robust security protocols in place to protect against such sophisticated attacks. It calls for immediate attention

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/agent-session-smuggling-in-agent2agent-systems/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_2568)**


---


### Chinese APT Uses ‚ÄòAirstalk‚Äô Malware in Supply Chain Attacks


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses a sophisticated cyberattack campaign orchestrated by a Chinese Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group, which has been leveraging a novel malware strain named "Airstalk" to conduct supply chain attacks. This campaign targets key industries by infiltrating their supply chains, thereby gaining access to critical information and compromising systems. The APT group's activities highlight the evolving nature of cyber threats that focus on exploiting vulnerabilities in supply chains, showcasing the need for robust cybersecurity measures and vigilant monitoring to protect against such breaches.

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.securityweek.com/chinese-apt-uses-airstalk-malware-in-supply-chain-attacks/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4142)**

üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


The article "Opt Out October: Daily Tips to Protect Your Privacy and Security" provides a series of daily actionable tips designed to enhance individuals' online privacy and security throughout the month. It covers various aspects of digital life, from managing personal data on social media platforms and enhancing password security to navigating privacy settings on mobile devices and employing encryption tools. The initiative aims to empower users with knowledge and practical steps to safeguard their information against potential cyber threats. Each tip is crafted to be easily implementable, making it

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/09/opt-out-october-daily-tips-protect-your-privacy-and-security?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_3708)**

### Aisuru Botnet Shifts from DDoS to Residential Proxies


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The Aisuru botnet, initially known for executing Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, has evolved its operations by transforming into a network of residential proxies. This shift indicates a strategic change in tactics, as the botnet now rents out its infected devices, enabling users to route their internet traffic through these compromised systems to mask their online activities and bypass geo-restrictions. The transformation highlights a growing trend of botnets adapting to monetize their networks through methods that do not immediately disrupt

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2025/10/aisuru-botnet-shifts-from-ddos-to-residential-proxies/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_9138)**


---


### Accurate Target Privacy Preserving Federated Learning Balancing Fairness and Utility


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses advancements in federated learning, a machine learning approach that enables model training across decentralized devices while maintaining data privacy. The focus is on achieving a balance between fairness, utility, and privacy, particularly when dealing with biased data distributions across different clients. By introducing novel algorithms and methodologies, the study aims to ensure that the developed models are both effective and equitable, minimizing disparities in model performance between different groups. Key contributions include the development of a framework that preserves individual data privacy while enhancing the overall accuracy

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.26841?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_2936)**

### ‚ö° Weekly Recap: Lazarus Hits Web3, Intel/AMD TEEs Cracked, Dark Web Leak Tool & More


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


In a recent cybersecurity weekly recap, significant developments were highlighted, including cyber attacks by the notorious Lazarus Group targeting Web3 platforms, the compromising of trusted execution environments (TEEs) from tech giants like Intel and AMD, and the emergence of a new tool designed for leaking information on the dark web. These events underscore ongoing security challenges within the digital space, emphasizing the need for enhanced security measures across emerging technologies and platforms.

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://thehackernews.com/2025/11/weekly-recap-lazarus-hits-web3-intelamd.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_7410)**

### Age Verification, Estimation, Assurance, Oh My! A Guide to the Terminology


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article titled "Age Verification, Estimation, Assurance, Oh My! A Guide to the Terminology" offers a comprehensive overview of the terminology and processes involved in determining user age online. It distinguishes between age verification, which requires official documentation to confirm age; age estimation, which uses algorithms to predict age based on biometric data; and age assurance, a broader term encompassing both verification and estimation methods. The guide highlights the growing need for accurate age checks to comply with legal regulations and protect minors online,

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/10/age-verification-estimation-assurance-oh-my-guide-terminology?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_2215)**

### Alleged Jabber Zeus Coder ‚ÄòMrICQ‚Äô in U.S. Custody


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


U.S. authorities have taken into custody a man known as "MrICQ," who is alleged to be the coder behind the Jabber Zeus malware. This malware was part of a widespread cybercriminal infrastructure that notoriously targeted and stole millions of dollars from numerous bank accounts globally. The arrest is part of ongoing efforts by law enforcement agencies to clamp down on cybercrime and dismantle networks that facilitate such activities. MrICQ's capture marks a significant development in these efforts, underscoring the importance of

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2025/11/alleged-jabber-zeus-coder-mricq-in-u-s-custody/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4105)**
